[[Vienna]], June 20, 1875--d. [[Mondsee]], [[Upper Austria]], July 4, 1946) was an [[Austria]]n [[paleontology|paleontologist]] and [[evolutionary biology|evolutionary biologist]]. Together with [[Louis Dollo]], he was the founder of [[paleobiology]] and studied the life and environment of fossilized organisms.<ref name=aeiou>{{Aeiou|.a/a011396.htm}}</ref> From 1917-1934 he was a university professor in Vienna and later headed the Institute of Paleontology at the [[University of Göttingen]].<ref name=aeiou/> He also explored the [[Drachenhöhle]] cave at [[Mixnitz]].<ref name=aeiou/> Abel earned a PhD, after studying both law and science, from the University of Vienna. He remained there as an assistant to [[Alpine orogeny|Alpine]] geologist [[Eduard Suess]], before being appointed a professor of paleontology. In 1914, Abel proposed that fossil [[dwarf elephant]]s inspired the myth of giant [[cyclops]]es, because the center nasal opening was thought to be a cyclopic eye socket.<ref>Adrienne Mayor, ''The First Fossil Hunters: Paleontology in Greek and Roman Times'' (Princeton University Press) 2000.</ref> In 1920 he was awarded the [[Daniel Giraud Elliot Medal]] from the [[United States National Academy of Sciences|National Academy of Sciences]].<ref name=Elliot>{{cite web|title=Daniel Giraud Elliot Medal|url=http://www.nasonline.org/site/PageServer?pagename=AWARDS_elliot|publisher=National Academy of Sciences|accessdate=16 February 2011}}</ref> ==Selected writings== * ''Einige Monstrositäten bei Orchideenblüthen'' (1897) * ''Ueber einige Ophrydeen'' (1898) * ''[http://biodiversitylibrary.org/page/40166200 Fossile Flugfische]'' (1906) * ''[http://biodiversitylibrary.org/page/16004254 Die Morphologie der Hüftbeinrudimente der Cetaceen]'' (1907) * ''[http://biodiversitylibrary.org/page/31957945 Paläobiologie der Cephalopoden aus der Gruppe der Dibranchiaten]'' (1916) ==Further reading== * Baumgartel, Hans.
